item.title: Ticket #1253 (mass edit mode could visually disambiguate comments awaiting moderation) created
item.dc:creator: skippy
item.description: The normal listing of comments displays comments awaiting moderation in a visually different style (a lighter grey); but there is no such visual indicator for these comments in mass editing mode.

item.title: Ticket #1252 (patch for next_post() and previous_post() to honor "same_category" ...) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: next_post() and previous_post() are deprecated in favor of next_post_link() and previous_post_link(). This change needs to be made in get_next_post() and get_previous_post(). next_post() and previous_post() can be updated to use get_next_post() and get_previous_post().

item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description: Feature: See ​http://www.php.net/manual/en/language.operators.comparison.php

item.title: Ticket #1248 (Editing posts produces linebreak madness) updated
item.dc:creator: michel v
item.description:
Could reproduce this behaviour with a trunk build, in Firefox. Couldn't reproduce it in any other browser except Gecko-based ones.

So it looks like Firefox (or [insert Gecko browser name here]) adds linebreaks in the textarea when it renders it. When WP receives the updated content, it sees linebreaks and adds br tags.

This looks like a Gecko-specific bug, that, given the platform's marketshare, ought to be worked around in WP.

item.title: Ticket #1248 (Editing posts produces linebreak madness) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1248 (Editing posts produces linebreak madness) created
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description: When writing long lines, WordPress automagically inserts linebreaks. This screws up the formatting if you edit a post.

item.title: Ticket #1247 (Can't upload images to blog via XML-RPC (i.e. using gnome-blog)) updated
item.dc:creator: glabelle
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1247 (Can't upload images to blog via XML-RPC (i.e. using gnome-blog)) created
item.dc:creator: glabelle
item.description:
When I try to upload an image to wordpress using an utily like gnome-blog I get the following error message:

The bloggerAPI server (​http://www.optimized.org/wordpress/xmlrpc.php) reported an error I don't understand: '405, No uploads allowed for this site.'.

The text is uploaded to blog but not the image. When I try to edit the post I can see the following:

<p><img src="None"/></p><p> My text here</p>

item.title: Ticket #1244 (Better get_links()) updated
item.dc:creator: MaThIbUs
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1244 (Better get_links()) created
item.dc:creator: MaThIbUs
item.description: I made some changes to code behind the get_links() function, check it out. Basically, I just applied WordPress's PHP coding style rules, and I made it output double quotes instead of those ugly single ones. Oh, and some typo got fixed, too. :)

item.title: Ticket #1243 (wp_trim_excerpt shouldn't be a filter, but called directly from ...) updated
item.dc:creator: wyrfel
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1243 (wp_trim_excerpt shouldn't be a filter, but called directly from ...) created
item.dc:creator: wyrfel
item.description: wp_trim_excerpt is a filter that is by default applied with priority 10 to the 'get_the_excerpt' filter hook. This means that filters don't get applied to the generated excerpt that are attached to the 'get_the_excerpt' hook with a priority <10.

item.description:
just wondering... in get_settings(), there is a line with:

if ($kellogs !== FALSE)

is this a typo, or feature?

similar question for:

if ($value === FALSE)

in get_alloptions()

item.title: Ticket #1241 (previous_post() and next_post() don't apply 'the_title' filters under ...) updated
item.dc:creator: wyrfel
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1241 (previous_post() and next_post() don't apply 'the_title' filters under ...) created
item.dc:creator: wyrfel
item.description:
In case that $title='yes', the following call is done:

$string .= wptexturize($nextpost->post_title);

This should be replaced to make use of the filtering system instead:

$string .= apply_filters('the_title', $nextpost->post_title);

item.title: Ticket #930 (Private posts not visible) updated
item.dc:creator: rsaldinger
item.description:
I see the same problem. Based on some old threads in the support forums, it seems that $user_ID isn't set at the time that this check happens in WP_Query::get_posts():

if (isset($user_ID) && ( != intval($user_ID)))

Consistent with that, I was able to get it work by adding a call to get_currentuserinfo() just prior to this check, but I have no idea if this is the "right" (or safe!) fix.
